pageData.text: In this experiment, students apply the concepts of solubility and magnetism to separate a <button class='glossary-text'>mixture</button> of four solids.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 5 minutes 
Activity 1: Separation of a Mixture – 120 minutes and overnight dry time

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Heat-resistant surface such as stovetop or trivet
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos

text: Describe the difference between <button class='glossary-text'>homogeneous</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>heterogeneous</button> <button class='glossary-text'>mixtures</button>.

pageData.text: Separating <button class='glossary-text'>mixtures</button> is important in the process of manufacturing chocolate. Initially, the beans are harvested and then left alone to ferment. After approximately seven days, the fermented beans are dried and are then separated from contaminants such as dried cocoa pulp, pieces of pod, and sand. Upon separation, the beans are roasted. After roasting, the thin shells of the cocoa beans become brittle, making them easier to separate. A winnowing machine passes the beans between serrated cones which crack the thin shells without crushing the bean. A series of mechanical sieves separate the broken shells and fans blow away the thin, light shells. The nibs are the heart of the chocolate we are familiar with, and they are processed further by large grinding stones that create a cocoa paste. The cocoa paste contains cocoa butter, which is typically a solid at room temperature, but the frictional heat produced from grinding liquifies it. At this point, the liquid is referred to as cocoa liquor. After resolidifying, this cocoa liquor is what we know as unsweetened chocolate. To create popular chocolate candies, cocoa liquor is combined with extra cocoa butter, sugar, milk, and a variety of other ingredients.

pageData.desc: A pile of partially-processed cacao beans.
pageData.altText: A pile of partially-processed cacao beans.

pageData.text: The building block of all matter is the <button class='glossary-text'>atom</button>. There are many varieties of atoms, called <button class='glossary-text'>elements</button>, which are the basis for the diversity of matter that exists around us. All elements, naturally occurring or manmade, appear on the <button class='resource-text'>periodic table</button>.

Furthermore, each of these elements can bond with other atoms. When that occurs, a <button class='glossary-text'>compound</button> is formed. When a solid is made entirely of one element or a single compound, it is considered to be pure. An example of a pure element is a gold bar. The bar is made entirely of gold atoms. An example of a pure compound is sucrose, commonly known as table sugar. Sucrose (C<sub class='bodysubscript'>12</sub>H<sub class='bodysubscript'>22</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>11</sub>) is a compound composed of 12 carbon atoms, 22 hydrogen atoms, and 11 oxygen atoms and is the only chemical in sugar crystals.

form when elements or compounds are added together without reacting with one another. Mixtures can be either , having a uniform composition at the molecular level throughout, or , not having a uniform composition throughout. An example of a homogeneous elemental mixture is the air we breathe. Air is comprised primarily of the elements nitrogen and oxygen and has a uniform composition. An example of a homogeneous mixture of compounds is salt water. Sodium chloride (table salt) is dissolved in water and the resulting solution has a uniform composition.

An example of a heterogeneous elemental mixture is diamonds in graphite. Both are entirely made of elemental carbon, but the carbon does not have a uniform composition; the diamonds can be easily separated from the graphite by hand. An example of a heterogeneous mixture of compounds is silicon dioxide, or sand, in water. Both are compounds, but the composition is not uniform, and each compound can be identified.

pageData.question: Why are diamonds in graphite considered a heterogeneous mixture?

options.text: Diamonds can be easily separated from graphite.
Diamonds chemically react to graphite.
Diamonds and graphite share electrons.
Diamonds and graphite can form covalent bonds.
Diamonds and graphite are both made of carbon.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Both diamonds and graphite are entirely made of elemental carbon, but the carbon does not have a uniform composition; the diamonds can be easily separated from the graphite by hand.

pageData.question: Air is considered what type of mixture?

options.text: homogeneous mixture
heterogeneous mixture
chemical mixture
uniform mixture
aqueous mixture

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Air is comprised primarily of the elements nitrogen and oxygen and has a uniform composition; therefore, it is considered a homogeneous mixture.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Mixtures can be either homogeneous, having a uniform composition at the molecular level throughout, or heterogeneous, not having a uniform composition throughout. An example of a homogeneous elemental mixture is the air we breathe. Air is comprised primarily of the elements nitrogen and oxygen and has a uniform composition. An example of a homogeneous mixture of compounds is salt water. Sodium chloride (table salt) is dissolved in water and the resulting solution has a uniform composition. An example of a heterogeneous elemental mixture is diamonds in graphite. Although both diamonds and graphite are entirely made of elemental carbon, the carbon in such a mixture does not have a uniform composition; the diamonds can be easily separated from the graphite by hand. Mixtures form when elements or compounds are added together without reacting with one another. An example of a heterogeneous mixture of compounds is silicon dioxide, or sand, in water. Both are compounds, but the composition is not uniform, and each compound can be identified.

An example of a heterogeneous elemental mixture is diamonds in graphite. Although both diamonds and graphite are entirely made of elemental carbon, the carbon in such a mixture does not have a uniform composition; the diamonds can be easily separated from the graphite by hand. Mixtures form when elements or compounds are added together without reacting with one another. An example of a heterogeneous mixture of compounds is silicon dioxide, or sand, in water. Both are compounds, but the composition is not uniform, and each compound can be identified.

pageData.text: In this experiment, a of four solids will be separated. Usually, one needs to determine not only the best methods, but also the best order in which to separate the components. provides some physical properties of the contents of the mixture that will aid in our approach to the separation.

Two observations may be made quickly after examining Table 1. First, the iron filings will be the easiest to remove from the sample since iron is the only material in the sample that is attracted to a magnet. This should be the first component to separate from the sample. Second, none of the materials have a melting point at a temperature that can be safely achieved in a home laboratory. Thus, using a selective melting method is not an option.
In looking at the solubility data of the remaining , silicon dioxide is not soluble in water, but the other chemicals are. Dissolving both benzoic acid and sucrose will leave silicon dioxide behind.

header.text: Solubility in Water at 0 °C

pageData.text: With the last two chemicals in an aqueous solution, a method for separating them from each other is crucial to the final step of the experiment. shows that the solubility of sucrose and benzoic acid are significantly different. At 0 ºC, benzoic acid is nearly insoluble in water. If the solution containing the remaining two is cooled as close to 0 ºC as possible, most of the benzoic acid will crystallize out and can be filtered from the sucrose solution.
Now that the methods for this separation have been identified and the order determined, we can develop a separation scheme, as shown in Figure 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: separation scheme for a mixture of iron filings, silicon dioxide, sucrose and benzoic acid
pageData.altText: Figure 1: separation scheme for a mixture of iron filings, silicon dioxide, sucrose and benzoic acid

pageData.question: In this investigation, how will you separate benzoic acid from sucrose?

options.text: by cooling the benzoic acid-sucrose solution
by heating the solid benzoic acid-sucrose mixture
by adding a strong acid to the benzoic acid-sucrose solution
by passing a magnet over the solid benzoic acid-sucrose mixture
by vigorously shaking the benzoic acid-sucrose solution

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: At 0 ºC, benzoic acid is nearly insoluble in water. If the solution containing the remaining two compounds is cooled as close to 0 ºC as possible, most of the benzoic acid will crystallize out and can be filtered from the sucrose solution.

pageData.question: To what temperature must the benzoic acid-sucrose solution be cooled to separate the mixture and which compound will crystallize out of solution?

options.text: 0 ºC; benzoic acid
0 ºC; sucrose
122 ºC; benzoic acid
186 ºC; sucrose
100 ºC; benzoic acid

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: At 0 ºC, benzoic acid is nearly insoluble in water. If the solution containing the remaining two compounds is cooled as close to 0 ºC as possible, most of the benzoic acid will crystallize out and can be filtered from the sucrose solution.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In this experiment, a mixture of four solids will be separated. Usually, one needs to determine not only the best methods, but also the best order in which to separate the components. The iron filings will be the easiest to remove from the sample since iron is the only material in the sample that is attracted to a magnet. This should be the first component to separate from the sample.  Using a selective melting method is not an option. Silicon dioxide is not soluble in water, but the other chemicals are. Dissolving both benzoic acid and sucrose will leave silicon dioxide behind. The last two chemicals are now in an aqueous solution. Table 1 shows that the solubility of sucrose and benzoic acid are significantly different. If the solution containing the remaining two compounds is cooled, one of the two remaining compounds will crystallize out and can be filtered from the solution.

If the solution containing the remaining two compounds is cooled, one of the two remaining compounds will crystallize out and can be filtered from the solution.

pageData.desc: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. Start by measuring the mass of the mixture sample. Next, separate the iron filings from the sample. Then, measure the mass of the iron filings, and dissolve the sample in hot water. Next, separate the sand from the dissolved sample, and cool the dissolved sample. Separate the benzoic acid from the dissolved sample and separate the sucrose from the water. Next, determine the masses of the sand, benzoic acid and sucrose. Finally, calculate the percentage of recovery.
pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. Start by measuring the mass of the mixture sample. Next, separate the iron filings from the sample. Then, measure the mass of the iron filings, and dissolve the sample in hot water. Next, separate the sand from the dissolved sample, and cool the dissolved sample. Separate the benzoic acid from the dissolved sample and separate the sucrose from the water. Next, determine the masses of the sand, benzoic acid and sucrose. Finally, calculate the percentage of recovery.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Use caution when heating water to 75–80 °C on a stovetop or in a microwave. If using a microwave, heat in short intervals, and check the temperature with a thermometer. Do not exceed 80 °C. Higher temperatures may melt the plastic graduated cylinder when measuring the water. Use an oven mitt or potholder when handling containers with hot water.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: The sample <button class='glossary-text'>mixture</button> contains benzoic acid, which is a health hazard. It is harmful if swallowed and causes skin irritation.
pageData.altText: warning symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area thoroughly with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following techniques is best for separating iron filings from a heterogeneous mixture?

options.text: expose the mixture to a magnet
melt the mixture at a high temperature
combine the mixture with warm water
combining the mixture with cold water
passing the mixture through a sieve

assestmentData.question: An aqueous solution at 25° C contains dissolved sucrose and benzoic acid. Which of the following techniques is best for separating the benzoic acid from the solution?

options.text: cool the solution to nearly 0° C
heat the solution to 100° C
pour the solution through filter paper
allow the water to evaporate overnight
add more sucrose to the solution

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT a compound?

options.text: Au (gold)
CO<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> (carbon dioxide)
H<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>O (water)
Cu<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>Zn<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> (brass)
C<sub class='bodysubscript'>8</sub>H<sub class='bodysubscript'>8</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub> (vanilla flavor)

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a homogenous mixture?

options.text: sugar water
chocolate chip cookie dough
fruit salad
a gold bar
water with ice cubes

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a heterogeneous mixture?

options.text: breakfast cereal with milk
salt water
the helium gas in a balloon
copper wire
a carbonated soft drink

assestmentData.question: The sample mixture provided in your lab kit for this investigation contains benzoic acid. Which of the following safety hazards is associated with this chemical?

options.text: It is harmful if swallowed.
It produces harmful fumes.
It is highly flammable.
It is a extremely toxic to aquatic life.
It can stain skin or clothing.

assestmentData.question: This investigation uses a glass thermometer. Which of the following best describes the safe disposal of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in a special receptacle on your school’s campus.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in a recycling bin.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following safety concerns is associated with the hot water you will use in this investigation?

options.text: Temperatures exceeding 80 °C may melt the plastic graduated cylinder.
Temperatures exceeding 100 °C may melt the iron filings in the sample mixture.
Temperatures exceeding 100 °C may crack the thermometer.
Temperatures exceeding 80 °C may initiate harmful fumes from benzoic acid.
Temperatures exceeding 80 °C may melt the gloves or lab apron.

Read the entire procedure before starting the activity.
Clear a work area for all lab materials.

In this activity, you will separate out the four different <button class='glossary-text'>compounds</button> that make up a <button class='glossary-text'>mixture</button> using various techniques. You will compare the mass of the mixture sample to the combined masses of each compound to calculate the percentage recovery.

pages.title: Separation of a Mixture (22 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Separation of a Mixture (22 steps)

pageData.text: Turn on the electronic balance. Place the weigh boat on the balance and tare the balance.

Open the packet and slowly dispense the contents into the weigh boat. Record the mass of the mixture sample in Data Table 1 and Data Table 2. Remove the weigh boat and its contents from the electronic balance.
Cut a small piece of plastic wrap approximately 6''× 6'' and place the magnet in the center. Pick up the plastic wrap by the corners so that the magnet is enclosed in the plastic wrap.

Slowly move the magnet, enclosed in plastic wrap, just above the mixture sample until you believe that all the iron has stuck to the magnet. Set the plastic wrap and magnet on the second weigh boat and remove the magnet from the plastic wrap. The iron shavings should deposit into the weigh boat. Take a photograph of the weigh boat.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Carefully remove the plastic wrap from the boat, making sure no shavings cling to the plastic wrap. Record the mass of the iron filings in Data Table 1.
Measure the mass of the empty plastic beaker and record it in Data Table 1.
Pour the remaining mixture sample from the weigh boat into the plastic beaker.
Measure approximately 50 mL of distilled water in the graduated cylinder and transfer it to a pot on the stovetop or a microwaveable container. Heat the water until it is between 75–80 °C.
Add the hot distilled water to the beaker containing the remaining mixture sample. Swirl. Let stand for 2 minutes on a heat-resistant surface.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: While the benzoic acid and sugar are dissolving, prepare an ice water bath in the bowl. Fill the bowl halfway full of ice, then add cold water until the ice just begins to float in the bowl.

<button class='glossary-text'>Decant</button> all the liquid from the beaker into a foam cup. Use a spoon if necessary, taking care not to transfer any solid to the foam cup. Set the beaker with the sand aside to dry overnight (it may take longer than a day).
When the sand appears dry, measure the mass of the beaker and sand. Record the mass in Data Table 1.

Place the foam cup containing the solution into the ice water bath and allow it to cool for approximately 10 minutes. During the cooling time, you may notice benzoic acid crystals forming in the liquid.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: While the liquid is cooling, fold the filter paper in half and then in half again. Take a photograph of filter paper. Measure its mass and record in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Fold the filter into a cone shape and set it into the funnel as shown in Figure 2. Wet the filter slightly with distilled water to get it to stick to the inside of the funnel.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram and photo showing how to fold filter paper and place it into the funnel.

pageData.text: Record the mass of the empty foam cup in Data Table 1.

While holding the funnel over the empty foam cup in one hand, slowly pour the solution with the crystals into the funnel with the other hand. Occasionally swirl the cup contents to ensure that no crystals remain in the cup.

Once all the liquid has poured through the filter paper, remove the filter paper from the funnel and set it aside to dry overnight. At the same time, allow the solution in the foam cup to dry overnight.
Once the filter paper is dry, measure the mass of the filter paper and its contents and take a photograph of this process. Record the mass in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Once all the liquid in the foam cup has evaporated, measure the mass of the cup and its contents. Record the mass in Data Table 1.

Calculate the mass of sand, benzoic acid, and sucrose by difference. Subtract the original mass of the container (beaker, filter paper, and coffee cup, respectively) from the mass of the dried sample with its container. Record those masses in Data Table 1.

Record the masses for iron, sand, benzoic acid, and sucrose from Data Table 1 in Data Table 2. Add each of these values together to determine total mass collected. Calculate the percentage recovery using the following formula.
Percentage recovery = Total mass of components /Original Mass of Mixture × 100%

text: Discard the components of the <button class='glossary-text'>mixture</button>, used filter paper, sheet of paper, and foam cups in the trash.
Wash and rinse the used equipment. Dry with a paper towel.
Return the materials to your equipment kit.

pageData.title: Questions
text: How did the total mass of the recovered chemicals compare to the original mass of the sample?
If your recovery mass was noticeably different from the original mass, can you determine some reasons for this discrepancy?
Which chemical in the separation do you believe was the most accurate to the original mass in the sample?  Why?
Which chemical in the separation do you believe was the least accurate to the original mass in the sample?  Why?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: separation scheme for a mixture of iron filings, silicon dioxide, sucrose and benzoic acid

This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. Start by measuring the mass of the mixture sample. Next, separate the iron filings from the sample. Then, measure the mass of the iron filings, and dissolve the sample in hot water. Next, separate the sand from the dissolved sample, and cool the dissolved sample. Separate the benzoic acid from the dissolved sample and separate the sucrose from the water. Next, determine the masses of the sand, benzoic acid and sucrose. Finally, calculate the percentage of recovery.
Figure 2: Diagram and photo showing how to fold filter paper and place it into the funnel.

data.title: Atom
data.content: The fundamental building blocks of matter, making up the 118 currently known elements, consist of three major particles: protons, neutrons, and electrons

data.title: Compound
data.content: Substance composed of identical molecules consisting of atoms of two or more chemical elements

data.title: Decant
data.content: Pour the liquid portion from one container to another with out disturbing the solid portion

data.title: Element
data.content: Pure substance consisting only of atoms that all have the same numbers of protons in their nuclei

data.title: Heterogeneous
data.content: Not having a uniform composition throughout

data.title: Homogeneous
data.content: Having a uniform composition at the molecular level throughout

data.title: Mixture
data.content: Form when elements or compounds are added together without reacting with one another
